Posted: May 31, 2015
												Beep is a great game, and definitely lives up to the claims it makes of being like yoshi island with gravity guns.Following a ship of robots [beeps], you aim to travel a solar system and collect anti-matter. The levels are your classic platformer side-scrolling style, but there is a lot of variety in landscapes, from levels that require a jetpack, to those in underground flooded caves. There are also enemies that you can either shoot or avoid. The majority of the gameplay is pretty casual, for example there is no limit on your ammo, you can reload an infinite amount of times. Some of the enemies require a bit of experimenting to find the best way to deal with them, which provides a challenge. That said, most of the enemies have a very simple AI.The gravity gun provides for some very interesting gameplay. You can pick up many objects, including enemies, which can lead to finding some interesting solutions [not always the intended ones] to progressing through levels. This coupled with the gravity reversal in the final zone definitely makes this a great gameplay object, rather than just a gimmick.The art in this game is very nice, and aside from a few [what i suspect are] spritesheet glitches when a certain enemy explodes, it is consistent throughout the game. On top of that, the music in this game is great.This game is also short. The main level selection screen shows you have essentially 6 'zones', each with 4 levels. If you are a veteran player of platformers like this, you will probably breeze through it in no time. Regardless, if you like platformers, you will also enjoy it very much.

Posted: October 14, 2016
												This is a very nice little puzzle platformer where the highlight of the game is the Box2D physics engine. The game is one big physics playground. Every world adds a new gameplay element, mostly physics based, that usually isn't used later, so it keeps the challenges and puzzles fresh. Some of the levels are quite big and it is unfortunate there are no secrets to find or achievements. The music is very nice and relaxing, and every world is not just visually unique, but has its own music theme too.One negative about the game are the mouse controls. The cursor doesn't move completely free, but "sticks" to certain objects and stuff, so it often feels clumsy. It takes some time to get used to. Other problem is the framerate which is quite unstable and drops below 60 FPS even on a powerful PC. I think I had more stable framerate in Crysis 1 than in this game.The game is not very challenging, just enough to keep your brain busy without the danger to get you stuck or get frustrated. I would highly recommend this for kids, to work on their problem solving and logic skills, or for casual players.

Posted: May 19, 2015
												so I played this game for 1 hour and I bought it for a 96% discount, so it costed me only 0.20$, my 1st expression when I saw this was like, might as well offer the game for free with this discount :) it`s original price is 5$, I have bought like 6 copies of these to send them as gifts. -gameplay:- the game is pretty easy to play and very fun, but one most be sort of skilled with keyboard and mouse to play the game enjoyably, I don`t think it supports gamepad.-graphics:- its one of the simplest 2d graphics I have seen but it`s crafted well and looks nice and smooth. I really love the simplicity factor but the menu layout could be better. -story and puzzles:- its about a robot ships being sent to out space in the future to discover planets in other galaxies. u simply orbit the planets with ur little rocket ship and hit deploy on various places on the planet to deploy the little cute catty sounded robot. u face plenty of obsacles and the game appears to have many missions, u have to stack stuff, block things and slide things to reach your goal. nothing too complicated but it`s fun and rewarding. conclusion: coming from a hardcore, eye candy fps, strategy and racing gamer, this game may not be as appealing but after I played it I truely loved it. it`s definitly a kid game. but one must always keep the inside kiddo in us alive and happy :) I`m definitly gifting alot of copies to my young cousins since they would love it:) I would say it's even worth 5$ full price and even better with 96% discount.

If you are a veteran player of platformers like this, you will probably breeze through it in no time. Regardless, if you like platformers, you will also enjoy it very much.

Posted: January 28, 2016
												Platformers, by and large come in two varieties:  Cute and Cuddly, and mentally difficult.   While things like SuperMeatBoy fall into the latter, this very firmly falls into the former.  Beep is, essentially, a keyboard/mouse physics puzzler/platformer crossover.  You take control of a little robot, exploring a solar system of three planets, 'beaming down' into level after level, looking for 'antimatter', and then beaming back up.The game features all the usual favourites of platformers - you'll be teetering on edges, jumping over enemies, sliding blocks, running on rotating drums, solving machine puzzles, shooting bullets, and my absolute #1 favourite: dying a lot.That's the thing about platformers: They're set up to kill you. Some are fierce and you're expected to die every 10 seconds, while others involve tactics, long run-ups, and really spectacular jumps (e.g. Sonic).  This falls midway between the two: It never presents a level which is ridiculously hard, usually giving you a relatively safe place you can 'fall' to, but although there are some really nice long jumps, and great swings, it doesn't have the majesty of AAA platformers like Sonic.This feels like an indie Flash game that outgrew the technology and needed to visit the big leagues.  It's cute, cuddly, easy to pick up, has good music, fun sound effects, and is nicely balanced.  There were very few occasions where I got truly narked with the level design, but generally, I found a better way to do it than I had been trying.The game rewards mild exploration.  Unlike some games that cheat with invisible doors, off-screen specials, or collapsing platforms, this game is pretty straight-up, and says "There's a special up here.  Come get it if you can work out how.".  I finished the game collecting every single last piece of antimatter, and didn't spend ages banging my fists in frustration either.So, yeah, this is a really really fun little game.  I don't recommend playing on a touchpad. It REALLY benefits from a mouse.  Similarly, if your mouse skills aren't great, I'd pass on this, cos you have to be a bit good on the point-and-click.  For the price, this gave a lot of entertainment, although not a lot of story per se.  The game hints to a sequel, which I'd consider playing if the price was as low as I got this one for.  Pick it up if you have a few hours to kill: Each level takes about 10 to 30 minutes to master and complete, so you can play it in short bursts.Great fun.

Posted: July 22, 2015
												There's something oddly satisfying about flinging dead robots across a screen.BEEP is a simple yet enjoyable platformer that puts your efforts toward solving puzzles using a robot (BEEP) and the game's physics engine. Most of the time these puzzles are fairly easy to figure out as you're primarily just moving rocks and logs around until you've found the correct setup to accomplish your goal, but the odd puzzle might leave you scratching your head on occasion. There are also enemies in the game that take the form of opposing robots, but they're so underwhelming and easy to destroy that they merely serve as a hindrance to your progression. From start to finish, you're probably looking at 5-7 hours worth of gameplay depending on how fast you manage to roll (or fly) through the worlds.This isn't the type of game that's going to leave you awestruck or clamoring for more once you've finished. It is however a game that you can jump straight into and play in a relaxing manner. It's fun, simple and essentially free if you purchase it during a sale. I actually made a profit of nine cents after selling the trading cards.  It's hard to argue against picking up a game when you're basically being paid to play it. Enjoy!

You take control of a little robot, exploring a solar system of three planets, 'beaming down' into level after level, looking for 'antimatter', and then beaming back up.The game features all the usual favourites of platformers - you'll be teetering on edges, jumping over enemies, sliding blocks, running on rotating drums, solving machine puzzles, shooting bullets, and my absolute #1 favourite: dying a lot.That's the thing about platformers: They're set up to kill you. Some are fierce and you're expected to die every 10 seconds, while others involve tactics, long run-ups, and really spectacular jumps (e.g. Sonic).  This falls midway between the two: It never presents a level which is ridiculously hard, usually giving you a relatively safe place you can 'fall' to, but although there are some really nice long jumps, and great swings, it doesn't have the majesty of AAA platformers like Sonic.This feels like an indie Flash game that outgrew the technology and needed to visit the big leagues.  It's cute, cuddly, easy to pick up, has good music, fun sound effects, and is nicely balanced.  There were very few occasions where I got truly narked with the level design, but generally, I found a better way to do it than I had been trying.The game rewards mild exploration.  Unlike some games that cheat with invisible doors, off-screen specials, or collapsing platforms, this game is pretty straight-up, and says "There's a special up here.  Come get it if you can work out how.".  I finished the game collecting every single last piece of antimatter, and didn't spend ages banging my fists in frustration either.So, yeah, this is a really really fun little game.  I don't recommend playing on a touchpad. It REALLY benefits from a mouse.  Similarly, if your mouse skills aren't great, I'd pass on this, cos you have to be a bit good on the point-and-click.  For the price, this gave a lot of entertainment, although not a lot of story per se.  The game hints to a sequel, which I'd consider playing if the price was as low as I got this one for.  Pick it up if you have a few hours to kill: Each level takes about 10 to 30 minutes to master and complete, so you can play it in short bursts.Great fun.

Posted: January 26, 2016
												I'll start by saing BEEP is probably worth $2.  My negative recommendation is not based on the monetary cost.  I wouldn't recommend BEEP simply because I don't think it's worth the time you would put into it.  Pretty much every part of BEEP can be considered "just good enough," but the game lacks polish in all departments.  The graphics aren't bad enough to be offensive, but don't really bring anything to the table.  The controls are adequate, but it's pretty obvious no effort was made to tighten them up or make them any better once an acceptable implementation was found.  The level design adequately makes the player use the game mechanics in the way they were intended to be use, but it seems like no one went and made the small adjustments to improve the gameplay ever so slightly.  Overall, it's just okay, and personally I don't think it's worth the time or effort.

Posted: October 29, 2015
												BEEP is a simple platformer. At a glance, this looks like a run-of-the-mill Mario or Sonic knockoff. However, BEEP is an entirely different type of platformer than others. I personally despise the genre, but I picked up the title for $0.19 regardless. I thought I'd try it for a couple minutes, hate it, and return it. However, I was laughing hard for a good hour. BEEP is extremely fun, the jet-propulsion is an amazing concept to introduce to a platformer. One of the best parts about this game is the gravity gun. You can swing enemies back in forth hilariously with it. The best part about this small game is the soundtrack. The music this game is set to is soothing and intriguing. And the sound effects are ever great. Typical robot sound effects sound annoying, but BEEP's sounds are simple and not too high pitched. This makes the game so inviting. I wouldn't buy this game at $5, because it goes on sale for $0.19 so often. The game takes a few days to complete even if you play diligently, so it's not like you play it for an hour or so and the game is complete. If you have a dollar in your Steam account, there's no reason to pick this title up when it's on sale.

Posted: April 4, 2016
												BEEP is a fun game including simple and more advanced puzzles, a cute story, cute world, cute characters, cute cute cute etc.. The price is also very nice (1$ or so); everyone can afford it. Depending on your skill, the game will take aprox. 3-4 hours to complete. There are 3 planets, with 2 worlds on each planet. Individually, there are 4 levels on each world. That's a total of 24 levels, with 6 different worlds (backgrounds). The music is quite nice, never being distracting unless you spend way too much time ♥♥♥♥ing around in one level. I wish there were more enemies and variety of weapons and puzzles.However, you should beware of some things within the game. For example, the game can't be played in full screen mode nor can the buttons be switched. The first issue can be fixed simply by pressing Alt+Enter to make it windowed mode. Another thing is an annoying bug on lava level 4 (last level). On the second checkpoint, there's a chance that the game will instantly crash on impact. This is kind of tricky to get past. The way I did it was to kill the robot previous to that area, and carry him to the second platform from the laser beam. From there, jump on the robot, pull the robot towards you and jump again so you get high enough to jump over it and past that checkpoint. There is also a chance the game with crash if you're hit by any other laser beams on the same level.Other than this, it's really worth the money. It's fun and mostly relaxing (unless you struggle or get stuck somewhere).Final rating: 7.5/10

Posted: June 7, 2015
												I purchased this game for about 14 cents, and while I did satisfy my curiousity, this game really began to grate me only half way through my first hour.The concept is charming enough, and the whole project just oozes cuteness, with the sounds that asteroids make when you bumb into them to the little phrases your robots utter when they do something notible or die. Infinite lives and fairly placed checkpoints were quite welcome, While it does have the atmosphere of a first time game, and while it came out a few years ago, it's a surprisingly competant one, especially given what Steam is saturated with nowadays, although the flash game aesthetic doesn't help.That being said, the floaty controls and precise platforming required do not make for a good time, although it doesn't start that way. Describing itself as a hardcore platformer to me indicates the controls and mechanics will be fine and precise, yet like the fleshed out flashgame it is, you won't find that here.Following basic platformer rules, BEEP introduces new mechanics every few levels or so, and getting the super hard to reach goodies even early on demand a mastery of them. However, you're little robot friend is quickly tasked with some fairly convoluted puzzles, implementing a poor man's gravity gun that doesn't work half the time, and when it does, it controls like dead animal caught in a wind turbine. Some enemies, which you can also use the g-gun on once killed, have parts that you can't hook onto, effectively turning off your beam and having you drop it. Repeatedly. This wouldn't be so bad  if there weren't areas that called for the use of these enemies, or the requirement to be precise with the positioning as you're forced to move quickly instead of methodically, but of course I wouldn't be complaining otherwise. It doesn't help that the gravity implemented is a pain in butt, and although you're little robot has a jetpack in which it can launch itself in the air and decent traction when it lands on an edge, you can't use it to stabilize or adjust mid jump, leading to some frustration on already floaty controls that are mired by the fact that majority of the game is just bland chasms with chunks of platforms spread far out of eyesight.It doesn't help that there is a function to fly, but it's purely locational, and only works when you find a pad that lets you charge it. Nevermind the fact that you can't use any remaining jump fuel to adjust, the fact it isn't a permanent upgrade, and something you have to constantly go back and recharge until you know exactly where you're going isn't my idea of fun. Implementing a metroid style progression system wouldn't be hard, and because I constantly felt underprepared no matter what level I went into left me more frustrated than anything. Combat is especially weak, and while your shield isn't awful, your gun is extremely weak. This being said, I barely managed to finish the second to last level of the first world out of sheer will before throwing in the towel, so if there are any permanent upgrades, I didn't find them. That isn't an excuse more so than it is to say that even the base game isn't great to play, and there is no driving incentive outside of seeing the next area, which is basically just a pallet swap of the last in one way or another.BEEP is not a bad game by any means, but it's not one I can reccomend. Still, since it was put on sale because of the studio about to announce a new game. I truly wish them all the luck, and for the small amount of pennies that they ask for on sale, it's worth it just for the trading cards. Regardless of how I feel about this game, it's without a doubt better than 90% of the other crap being dumped onto steam, so hopefully they've improved over the last few years.

Posted: September 25, 2015
												Considering I only paid 19 cents for this game, it's going to stay.TL/DR: BEEP is a OK game, but not worth $5. If you REALLY have to have it, wait for a sale,Graphics: 4/10. Looks/feels rushed, can sometimes be hard to tell what is a wall or not. Each menu looks like a 30 second project. (Or a last-minute thing.)Gameplay: 6/10. Good ideas, but not the most straightforward sometimes. The Gravity Gun would sometimes not latch on properly and disconnect at random. The game itself also assumes that you know what you can or cannot shoot. I had spent about 6 lives trying to pass a set of lasers using a defeated enemy, only to find that I could shoot them. One level in particular drove me nuts with having to build a set of platforms, and then giving you a Rocket system once completed. Needless to say, I somewhat lost hope in it after that.Sound: 4/10 Not really worth writing about, although some of the effects do get annoying rather quickly. Overall: 3/10 At full price. 4/10 discounted. Utter confusion, odd/cheap looking graphics, and an overall rushed feel put down some rather great ideas.

Posted: May 20, 2016
												What a bloody mad brilliant genius was the man ... nay, for 'twas no mere man who conceived BEEP.  What a smashing piece of work is BEEP. I don't go in much for platformers since they tend to be MASOCHISTICALLY DIFFICULT in the tradition of say, Super Meat Boy, and who has time for that? BEEP is a kinder gentler, machine, but still will make you work for every inch of progress, the way a good game should. It's also not burdened by the sombre gothic tone of so many games in the genre, think Limbo, or whatnot. It doesn't take itself too seriously but still there were a few nuggets of wisdom. "Incentive is the mother of inspiration". I'm paraphrasing. Badly. For a platformer BEEP is also not as linear as some, since there is usually more than one way to tackle a puzzle, and more than one path you can take. It's more of an open concept world, but not so big as to be unmanageable in a lunch break. You could pick away at BEEP one deployment at a time in the precious few spare moments that busy modern life grudgingly flicks your way. A  PARENT of TWINS could even play this game. That's saying a thing.The only thing I would change, if I were the game designer, heaven forfend, is to remove the 'continue/ship/quit' menu when you lose a BEEP but rather just drop another one immediately at the save point. After all if the player doesn't want to continue, they can just pause to hit the menu and scarper like the cowards they are, no need to interrupt the flow, and BEEP has amazing flow, so that's a minor quibble.It's now just a buck. There are so many worse ways to spend a buck. Well actually not that many since nothing costs a dollar anymore. This makes BEEP the best deal in the world.  That's math, people.We await the SEQUEL. BEEP2 : The EnBEEPening.

												At first I truly enjoyed the game but after a bunch of levels, it became mundane. BEEP eventually felt like an unpolished platformer due to its flash-like graphics and exploitable physics. It was also baffling for me that there was no option menu especially for those times when the game glitches in choosing the correct resolution. The ideas were whole but the cohesion of all the elements weren't quite there; it looked complete but slowly fell apart as I progressed through.

Posted: September 25, 2015
												This is not a word I use to describe games much, if at all, but the game is very cute. The robot known as a beep, is very much like a WALL-E, and makes appropriate "cute" sounds. I actually crack up quite a bit from the sounds it makes, and the art style and music also follows along with the theme.The puzzles aren't too difficult, and the platforming is very forgiving. The jumps are very floatly, with a very generous gliding back down to the ground. Combine that with the anti-gravity gun, and you have some good control over the robot. He even goes up surfaces with it's wheels that you wouldn't think he could climb up.I would say content wise, the game is safe for children, however some puzzles might cause the child to want some adult help. Even still, I think the game is friendly to people of all ages, and I highly recommend the game. I was thinking this was a game I'd only farm trading cards out of, given the extremely low price. Instead, I found a game I intend to play through, and enjoy very much.A surprise, and an enjoyable one at that.

Posted: July 16, 2015
												Usually, I try to finish a game before I review it because it might add new features and gameplay elements or because I want to see the story. However, this game had none of that. Beep is a 2d puzzle platformer where you control a little robot which has the power to shoot bullets, ability to "fly" with fuel, and move objects around with what is basically a gravity gun. This game has no story. There is a little blurb at the beginning about you being dropped off to visit various planets but it doesn't come up during gameplay. The game is dull. The levels feel repetitive  to the point where I just want to get to the ending. That wouldn't be a problem except... You have to find 3 'stars' on each level. It doesn't say it outright but mathwise, you have to. The first world has 8 levels with 3 stars each. The next world needs 24 stars to unlock (for some reason). You can technically get an extra star on every level by collecting all the mini stars but they are a pain to find because there are so many of them The music is just not good. I was going to play to the end just to get through the puzzles but the game is just way too boring to let any of that happen. Additionally, It put up arbitrary walls in front of me which just annoyed me until I stopped. You might like it but I did not.

Posted: January 8
												TL;DR: This game is worth every penny, ignoring the bundle price and the trading cards.Well, BEEP may look simple, it is VERY CHALLENGING in the later levels. The concept is simple, and so are the controls. There are tips here and there so you won't be wondering what the hell you are supposed to do. Though, in some part of the game, you can take the unconventional (and easy) way to collect those anti-matter nuggets.The game has amazing physics, even with unusually shaped objects. The combat system (morea accurately, aiming system) is also simple. Your crosshair locks onto targets and you can shoot like a pro while you jump here and there. There's that infinite ammo thing (you have to reload though, either by right clicking on your robot or by pressing "R") so you don't have to worry about missing a shot. You have an antigravity beam which allows you to move objects (even enemy corpses) and you will feel the incredible physics this game is offering. You robot's wheels have a good grip and you won't slip off edges easily.Now coming to the graphics and music. Everything is cartoon-ish, and the music is electronic blip blop type. I personally like both of them but many people hate these type of things. It's upto one's own aesthetics.The game interface is simple. TOO SIMPLE. You don't get to tweak any type of settings. You can't change the volume, you can't modify your save files and so on. This is basically the only side of the game that I hate.The game has trading cards, adding badges, backgrounds and emoticons, adding another layer of variety.Overall, this is a solid game.

Posted: January 7
												Bear in mind I've only played a specifically short time. But having played a couple levels I feel as though I've seen the very basics of what the game has to offer.If you're into silly platformers or you have kids that are into silly platformers, BEEP is worth checking out. Definitely a childish art style for a game that still holds enough challenge to have the ability to hold an adult's interest. It's very light and goofy, unlike almost every other game I enjoy. If you want to skip your gore for a night, BEEP is a great choice. Being 1.99, you can expect to get about two dollars of enjoyment from it. It's the same price as going to the dollar store and getting a soda and a bag of chips. But I tend to finish my food rather quickly and finish games rather slowly, so beep will definitely be enjoyable long after my snacks are gone. If you REALLY want a cheeseburger right away, BEEP can wait. But if you happen to have a couple bucks to spend and nothing else sparks your interest, you might want to pick it up and give it a try.

Posted: January 29
												This game is one of the best indie games I have played yet. This game combines some of the best aspects of 90s platformers with Half-life 2, creating a unique combunation that works. This game you can tell was made for PC, in fact I can't see this working on console because it requires the mouse to be used a lot in a fasion that would not fit console. It also has a cute, relaxing presentation and it has some clever physics puzzles, that is very reminicent of Half-life, but on a 2D plane which makes for some unique situations. The platforming is prety floaty, which some people may love or hate, but I think it fits the game's style perfectly. Overall, this game is defently worth the dollar, or $0.25 I got it for. Overall rating 9.1/10

Posted: February 4
												Beep was great; straight to the point, challenging, exactly as advertised, and far from pricey! If you liked yoshi’s island, or similar platformers, you’ll likely love this. The graphics aren’t very eye grabbing but the game designers more than makes up for it with great level designs, easy to learn/hard to master controls and really well executed puzzle concepts.In all honesty Beep is a boon to it’s genre; if all platformers where like this the genre would probably be immensely more popular. At first all the game elements might seem complex (the gun, the gravity gun, the Beep controls, etc) but they all come together so perfectly and are so intuitive that they actually feel simple and easy to manage. When you play Beep you can really feel that platformers are the game designers bread and butter; Big Fat Alien know what they’re doing.
